If used directly from the deep freezer, they can freeze vaccines like DPT, Hepatitis B, and Pentavalent, which should never be frozen. B. 320 ml capacity The capacity of vaccine carriers varies, but 320 ml is not a standard size. Most vaccine carriers have a larger volume, generally measured in liters, not milliliters. C. Has 2 holes for keeping reconstituted BCG & OPV Vaccine carriers do not have designated holes for keeping reconstituted vaccines. Instead, reconstituted vaccines should be kept in a separate compartment or a foam pad inside the carrier and used within 6 hours.

questions.text: Maximum chance of cold chain failure is at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Subcenter). Cold chain failure refers to a break in the required temperature range (+2°C to +8°C for most vaccines and -15°C to -25°C for frozen vaccines like OPV and varicella) during storage or transport, leading to vaccine damage. Subcenters are the lowest level in the healthcare delivery system and are often located in remote and rural areas. Factors leading to higher chances of cold chain failure at subcenters: Lack of proper storage facilities – Many subcenters do not have ILRs (Ice Lined Refrigerators) and rely on vaccine carriers. Frequent power cuts – Rural areas often experience unstable electricity supply, making it difficult to maintain the required cold temperatures. Longer vaccine transportation times – Vaccines are transported from higher centers (PHC/CHC) to subcenters, increasing exposure to temperature variations. Lack of trained personnel – Healthcare workers at subcenters may not be well-trained in cold chain management, increasing the risk of errors. Thus, subcenters have the highest risk of cold chain failure, making Option A the correct answer. Incorrect Options: B. PHC (Primary Health Center) PHCs have better infrastructure than subcenters, including Ice Lined Refrigerators (ILRs) and cold boxes to store vaccines. Power supply issues may still occur, but backup solutions (solar fridges, generators) are more likely to be available than at subcenters. C. CHC (Community Health Center) CHCs are larger facilities with more reliable cold chain equipment, such as deep freezers and ILRs. They also have trained staff and better power backup, reducing the chance of cold chain failure. D. District Hospital District hospitals are at the highest level of vaccine storage at the district level and are equipped with: Large walk-in coolers (WICs) and freezers (WIFs). Dedicated cold chain handlers and staff trained in vaccine storage and transport. Reliable power supply with backup generators. Since district hospitals have the best resources, cold chain failure is least likely here.

questions.text: Which of the following are not true regarding open vail policy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (All vaccines which are not reconstituted can be reused for up to a maximum of 3 months). The Open Vial Policy (OVP) is a guideline by the WHO that allows the reuse of certain multi-dose vials in subsequent immunization sessions under specific conditions. However, the statement in option B is incorrect because: Only certain vaccines (such as OPV, Hepatitis B, TT, and Pentavalent) can be used for up to 28 days after opening, not 3 months. Vaccines must be stored properly in the ILR (+2°C to +8°C) and should not show any signs of contamination or VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor) color change. Reconstituted vaccines (like BCG, MR, and JE) must be discarded after 6 hours and cannot be reused. Since no vaccine under the open vial policy can be stored for 3 months after opening, option B is incorrect and is the correct answer to the question. Incorrect Options: A. Reconstituted vaccines can’t be reused Live, lyophilized (powder) vaccines, such as BCG, Measles, MR, and JE, must be discarded within 6 hours after reconstitution. This is because reconstituted vaccines lack preservatives and are prone to bacterial contamination. C. Expired vaccines are not used Expired vaccines should never be used as they may be ineffective or harmful. Expiry dates are strictly followed under immunization programs. D. VVM has not been submerged in water The Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) is a heat-sensitive indicator that helps determine vaccine potency. If a vial is submerged in water, the integrity of the rubber seal may be compromised, leading to contamination. If the VVM is damaged, the vaccine should be discarded.

questions.text: A vaccine is given orally, it is live attenuated vaccine, 5 drops are given at 6, 10, 14 weeks. This vaccine is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Rotavirus vaccine). The Rotavirus vaccine is a live attenuated oral vaccine given to protect against rotavirus diarrhea, a leading cause of severe dehydration in infants. The vaccine is administered orally in 5 drops per dose at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age as part of the routine immunization schedule. It is a live attenuated vaccine, meaning the virus has been weakened so that it stimulates an immune response without causing disease. Thus, based on the route (oral), schedule (6, 10, 14 weeks), and type (live attenuated), the correct answer is Rotavirus vaccine (Option D). Incorrect Options: A. OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) – Incorrect OPV is also a live attenuated oral vaccine given in drops, but: The dose is 2 drops, not 5 drops. OPV is given at birth (zero dose) and at 6, 10, and 14 weeks, followed by booster doses. Since the question specifies 5 drops, OPV is incorrect. B. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus) – Incorrect DPT is not an oral vaccine; it is given intramuscularly (IM). It is also not a live attenuated vaccine; it contains inactivated bacterial toxoids and whole-cell pertussis antigen. C. PCV (Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine) – Incorrect PCV is not given orally; it is administered intramuscularly. It is not a live attenuated vaccine; it is a conjugate vaccine made from bacterial polysaccharides.

questions.text: You are the medical officer at a hospital, an ANC patient visits your hospital to enquire about the vaccination during pregnancy. Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated during pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (Varicella Vaccine) Live attenuated vaccines are generally contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of fetal infection and teratogenic effects. The varicella vaccine (chickenpox vaccine) is a live attenuated virus vaccine and should not be given during pregnancy. Varicella infection during pregnancy can cause congenital varicella syndrome, leading to limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, eye abnormalities, and neurological defects. If a pregnant woman is not immune to varicella and is exposed, she should receive Varicella-Zoster Immunoglobulin (VZIG) within 96 hours to prevent severe infection. Women should be vaccinated before pregnancy and advised to avoid conception for at least one month after receiving the varicella vaccine. Thus, Option B is correct as the varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy. Incorrect Options: A. "Hepatitis B vaccine" – Incorrect Hepatitis B vaccine (HBV) is a killed/inactivated vaccine, making it safe during pregnancy. It is recommended for pregnant women at risk of Hepatitis B infection to protect both the mother and the baby. C. "Influenza vaccine" – Incorrect The inactivated influenza vaccine is safe and recommended during pregnancy to prevent complications from influenza, which can be severe in pregnant women. However, the live attenuated intranasal flu vaccine (FluMist) is contraindicated in pregnancy. D. "Tetanus toxoid" – Incorrect Tetanus toxoid (TT) is safe and essential during pregnancy to prevent maternal and neonatal tetanus. TT vaccination schedule for pregnant women: First pregnancy: 2 doses (TT1 and TT2, given 4 weeks apart). Subsequent pregnancies: If the mother received two doses previously, only a booster is needed.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is associated with use of rotavirus vaccine?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (Intussusception) Rotavirus vaccine is associated with an increased risk of intussusception, a condition where part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. Mechanism: The vaccine stimulates intestinal immunity, which may cause lymphoid hyperplasia in Peyer’s patches, leading to bowel invagination. Incidence: The absolute risk is very low (~1-2 additional cases per 100,000 vaccinated infants), but it is higher than in unvaccinated infants. Timing: Intussusception typically occurs within 1–2 weeks after the first or second dose. Despite this small risk, the benefits of the rotavirus vaccine far outweigh the risks, as it significantly reduces severe diarrhea, hospitalizations, and deaths from rotavirus infection worldwide. Incorrect Options: A. Guillain-Barré Syndrome Not associated with the rotavirus vaccine. More commonly linked to other infections (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, influenza). B. Hemolytic Anemia No documented evidence linking rotavirus vaccine to hemolytic anemia. Hemolytic anemia is more commonly associated with certain infections or medications. C. Febrile Seizures Rotavirus vaccine is not a common cause of febrile seizures. Vaccines like MMR (Measles-Mumps-Rubella) and influenza vaccines have a stronger association with febrile seizures.

questions.text: A forest ranger presents to the emergency room because he was bitten on the hand by a wild dog while trying to capture the animal, which appeared ill. He states he received a primary course of rabies vaccination 3 years ago when he first started his job. The wound is immediately thoroughly cleaned by the ER staff. It is small because he was wearing gloves but bite marks are visible. Which is the most appropriate intervention for rabies prevention?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Administer two doses of vaccine) Since the forest ranger previously received a primary rabies vaccination series, the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) in previously vaccinated individuals differs from that of unvaccinated individuals. Rabies Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) Guidelines for Previously Vaccinated Individuals: Thorough wound cleaning (already done in the ER). Administer 2 booster doses of rabies vaccine (Day 0 and Day 3). Rabies immune globulin (RIG) is NOT required because the individual has already been vaccinated and has developed memory immunity. Since the forest ranger had the primary rabies vaccination series 3 years ago, he still has immune memory, but a booster is required for an effective immune response. Incorrect Options: A. No further prophylaxis is necessary – Incorrect Even though the ranger was vaccinated 3 years ago, rabies PEP still requires booster doses after an exposure. Immunity from prior vaccination wanes over time, so a booster enhances immune response. Therefore, some prophylaxis is necessary (Option A is incorrect). B. Administer rabies immune globulin (RIG) only – Incorrect RIG is NOT needed for previously vaccinated individuals because their immune system can mount a response with just a booster. RIG is only given to individuals who have never been vaccinated to provide passive immunity while their body generates an immune response. D. Administer one dose of vaccine only – Incorrect Two doses of vaccine (Day 0 & Day 3) are required for adequate protection. A single dose is insufficient to ensure long-term immunity.

questions.text: Consider the following conditions, Under which condition should chemoprophylaxis for influenza be considered?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (All hospital residents and unvaccinated staff during an influenza A outbreak) Chemoprophylaxis for influenza is an essential strategy to prevent the spread of infection, especially in high-risk institutional settings such as hospitals and nursing homes. Influenza A outbreaks can spread rapidly, leading to severe complications, particularly in elderly or immunocompromised individuals. Recommended Chemoprophylaxis Strategy During an Influenza A Outbreak: All hospital residents should receive antiviral chemoprophylaxis because they are at high risk of severe disease and complications. Unvaccinated staff are also at risk of both acquiring and transmitting the virus, so they should receive chemoprophylaxis. Common antiviral agents used include Oseltamivir (Tamiflu) or Zanamivir, given for at least 2 weeks or until the outbreak subsides. Since influenza A is more likely to cause severe outbreaks with antigenic shifts (leading to pandemics), all individuals in a hospital setting should be considered for prophylaxis. Incorrect Options: B. All hospital residents and unvaccinated staff during an influenza B outbreak While influenza B can also cause outbreaks, it is generally less severe and less likely to cause pandemics than influenza A. Chemoprophylaxis is still recommended in some cases, but the risk of widespread severe illness is lower than with influenza A. Influenza A outbreaks pose a greater threat, justifying broader prophylaxis. C. Only unvaccinated hospital residents and staff during an influenza A outbreak This option is too restrictive. Even vaccinated residents may not have full protection (especially elderly or immunocompromised individuals). Vaccination does not provide immediate immunity, and effectiveness varies yearly due to antigenic drift. Therefore, both vaccinated and unvaccinated hospital residents should receive chemoprophylaxis. D. Only unvaccinated hospital residents and staff during an influenza B outbreak Similar to option C, this answer fails to account for vaccinated residents who may still be at risk. While chemoprophylaxis is useful in influenza B outbreaks, it is more strongly recommended for influenza A due to its greater epidemic potential. The correct approach is to cover all hospital residents during an outbreak, not just the unvaccinated.
